descript.abstract: Two core indicators are calculated from this test: the average surface stability value and the average sub-surface stability value. The percentage of the surface samples tested that are equal to 6 (very stable) is another useful indicator that is easy to calculate. Both are correlated with all three ecosystem attributes. Higher stability has been directly correlated with reductions in erosion. Reference(s): Herrick, J.E., J. Van Zee, S.E. McCord, J.W. Karl, E. Courtright, and L. Burkett. 2018. The Monitoring Manual for Grassland, Shrubland, and Savanna Ecosystems. USDA-ARS.
descript.purpose: The soil stability test is a relatively simple test that is sensitive to complex changes in physical, chemical and biological processes. These are the processes that glue soil particles together. Soil stability at different depths and under different types of vegetation can be used to reflect changes in organic matter cycling.

attr.attrdef: Code denoting original database information about the project.
Unique identifier of the broader project under which data were collected.
Unique key for Soil Stability data collection.
Form for Soil Stability data collection.
Date data were collected (defaults to today's date although user can modify).
Surface only or surface and subsurface samples. 1 = surface only; 2 = surface and subsurface.
Line ID where samples were collected.
Position number along the line that soil stability sample was taken.
Position on transect (line) where sample was collected.
Vegetation where sample was collected (NC = no cover; C = Canopy; G = perennial grass and grass/shrub mixture; M (or MC, MN)= root mat; F = perennial forb; Sh = shrub canopy; or T = tree canopy).

Stability value (1 = 50% of structural integrity lost (melts) within 5 seconds of immersion in water AND <10% remains after 5 dipping cycles OR soil too unstable to sample (falls through sieve); 2 = 50% of structural integrity lost (melts) 5-30 seconds after immersion AND <10% remains after 5 dipping cycles; 3 = 50% of structural integrity lost (melts) 30-300 seconds after immersion OR < 10% of soil remains on the sieve after five dipping cycles; 4 = 10""""25% of soil remains on the sieve after five dipping cycles; 5 = 25""""75% of soil remains on the sieve after five dipping cycles; or 6 = 75""""100% of soil remains on the sieve after five dipping cycles.)
Indicates sample is hydrophobic when checked (1 = yes; 0 = no).
Notes about the Soil Stability data collection for the transect (line).
Source data format. Required for use of terradactyl
